Event.name: ReactEurope
Event.tag_line: The original React.js conference in Europe.
Event.description:
ReactEurope is back on 2-3 June 2016 to bring you the best and most passionate people from the very core team to the coolest people from the community we love. The conference aims to give talks that inspire and explore new futuristic ideas dealing with all the techs we enjoy including React.js, React Native, GraphQL, Relay, Universal apps, inline CSS and more.

ReactEurope is also a great occasion to socialize, meet new people and old friends, hack together, taste delicious food and have fun in the beautiful city of Paris.

Join us at ReactEurope Conf to shape the future of client-side, mobile and universal applications!
Event.description_tickets_page:
ReactEurope is back on 2-3 June 2016 to bring you the best and most passionate people from the very core team to the coolest people from the community we love. The conference aims to give talks that inspire and explore new futuristic ideas dealing with all the techs we enjoy including React.js, React Native, GraphQL, Relay, Universal apps, inline CSS and more.

ReactEurope is also a great occasion to socialize, meet new people and old friends, hack together, taste delicious food and have fun in the beautiful city of Paris.

ALL SALES ARE FINAL - NO REFUNDS but tickets are transferable
Event.speakers_legend: ReactEurope will feature core-team and top community members from your favorite technologies with a diverse range of expertise from all around the globe. Stay tuned for the Call for Paper announcement.

Proposals.title: Keynote
Proposals.description: Keynote

speakers.name: Dan Abramov
speakers.bio: Making hot reloading mainstream. Created React Hot Loader, Redux, React DnD.

Proposals.title: Native Navigation for Every Platform
Proposals.description: Navigation on native mobile apps can be very tricky. Unlike the browser, mobile apps have no built-in navigation system, and the navigation state is often deeply nested. Animations and gestures are critical for mobile apps, and are tricky to get right. To help the community address these concerns, I will introduce and demo our new navigation system for React Native, and show what innovations we can bring back to the web.

speakers.name: Eric Vicenti
speakers.bio: Working on React Native and using it to build cross-platform apps at Facebook since 2014.

Proposals.title: Coffee Break
Proposals.description: Socialize, have some coffee or other drinks.

Proposals.title: A cartoon guide to performance in React
Proposals.description: Everyone talks about how performant React is... but why? What makes people talk about how speedy React is? In this talk, you'll learn *why* people talk about React being fast, and what you can do to make it faster.

speakers.name: Lin Clark
speakers.bio: Code cartoonist and developer tools engineer at Mozilla.

Proposals.title: React Native <3 60FPS -- Improving React Native animations>
Proposals.description: Coming soon...

speakers.name: Krzysztof Magiera
speakers.bio: Software engineer working on @ReactJS Native for android.

Proposals.title: French Buffet
Proposals.description: Lunch time! Socialize while eating at our delicious buffet.

Proposals.title: Being Successful at Open Source
Proposals.description: I've been directly involved in the open source process of many Facebook projects such as React, React Native, css-layout, mention-bot and Jest in the past 3 years. We've tried a lot of different things in order to grow a community around those projects and I want to take this opportunity to share what worked for us and can likely be applied to other projects.

speakers.name: Christopher Chedeau
speakers.bio: Frenchy Front-end Engineer at Facebook. Working on React and React Native.

Proposals.title: GraphQL at Facebook
Proposals.description: Facebook has been using GraphQL in production for almost four years; today, it serves over 300 billion queries a day and its schema has nearly 10,000 types. In building this API, we‚Äôve developed a set of best practices for designing an understandable and scalable GraphQL schema. Based on real examples in Facebook‚Äôs production GraphQL API, we'll discuss common GraphQL patterns, how they differ from other best practices, and their implications on server and client design.

speakers.name: Dan Schafer
speakers.bio: Software engineer at Facebook, GraphQL co-creator.

Proposals.title: Coffee Break
Proposals.description: Socialize, have some coffee or other drinks.

Proposals.title: A Deepdive Into Flow
Proposals.description: Many have heard about Flow and some are using it a lot already, but what is it that makes Flow so powerful? I'll dive deeper into Flow, how it works, and why we're using it at Facebook to improve the quality of our code at scale.

speakers.name: Jeff Morrison
speakers.bio: Jeff works on @flowtype at Facebook.

Proposals.title: Debugging flux applications in production
Proposals.description:
We have brilliant tools and highly efficient practices for developing and debugging flux applications. But it‚Äôs not that easy when it comes to deal with troubles in production, especially with bug reports like ‚Äúnothing works‚Äù. The predictable states could help a lot, but user actions along with API calls are not that predictable.

This talk will dive into how to firmly debug client-side state for web and native flux applications, how to reproduce the exact state despite of diverse factors, track the original cause and get fixes out to users. You‚Äôll push development to the next level and improve user experience.

speakers.name: Mihail Diordiev
speakers.bio: Debugging geek, cares too much. Created Redux DevTools Extension, Remote Redux DevTools, RemoteDev and CrossBuilder.

Proposals.title: Coffee Break
Proposals.description: Socialize, have some coffee or other drinks.

Proposals.title: On the Spectrum of Abstraction
Proposals.description: JavaScript and the React community have evolved over the years through all the ups and downs. This talk goes over the tools we've come to recognize, from Angular, Ember and Grunt, all the way go Gulp, Webpack, React and beyond, and captures all these in a unifying mental framework for reasoning in terms of abstraction levels, in an attempt to make sense of what is and might be happening.

speakers.name: Cheng Lou
speakers.bio: React core member. Currently working on animation-related problems.

Proposals.title: React Redux Analytics
Proposals.description:
The Lean Startup advocates an iterative approach to finding the right product and market, with a constant cycle of building, measuring and learning. Lean Analytics is a new approach which dives deeper into the measurement component of this process. With Lean Analytics we can measure the state of the application and make informed decisions about the product and its vision based on end user interactions.
Redux allows us to maintain our application state in a single store, and provides a single location for state changes. By hooking analytics into this event loop we can infer a lot about end user behaviour. Our Redux Segment middleware allows you to draw deep and rich analytics from your Redux application with minimal configuration.
In this talk, we will walk through the process of adding analytics to your existing Redux application and share our implementation which works with segment.io.

speakers.name: Evan Schultz
speakers.bio: Evan is a passionate software developer with nearly 10 years experience. As a seasoned JavaScript architect he adapts to new technologies and has contributed to many team-based projects, whilst mentoring other developers. Evan leads and contributes to the Rangle.io‚Äôs  guidelines, code reviews and training material. He educates peers and clients and writes about development best practices for Rangle.io‚Äôs blog, http://blog.rangle.io

speakers.name: Bertrand Karerangabo
speakers.bio: Bertrand is a full-stack web developer with extensive experience building complex applications in ReactJS on web and native platforms. He also spends his time managing everything from server infrastructure to analytics dashboard.

Proposals.title: Lightning talks session
Proposals.description: Small five minute short talks on React and its ecosystem.

Proposals.title: Dinner
Proposals.description: Drinks, food, music.

Proposals.title: Check-in
Proposals.description: Make sure to get in early.

Proposals.title: Breakfast
Proposals.description: Your typical French breakfast with croissants, coffee and more.

Proposals.title: Evolving the Visual Programming Environment with React
Proposals.description: Tools shape our thinking. The "React Way" of thinking has already found many applications beyond building user interfaces. Particularly, React's functional, component-based design makes it an ideal candidate for building a better Visual Programming Environment. We'll examine how to overcome challenges such as lack of standardized APIs and limits of composition, and show how we can drastically improve the way humans create digital artifacts today.

speakers.name: Jonas Gebhardt
speakers.bio: Front-end Engineer at Facebook Seattle, working on Nuclide & building tools to empower humans.

Proposals.title: React Native Retrospective
Proposals.description: Remember when React Native beta access was shared illicitly via flash drives behind closed doors? Since its first release in January 2015, React Native has experienced incredible growth and adoption. We'll discuss the evolution of React Native over the last year, looking at the maturation of the library as well as the ever-increasing community around it. From the release of Android support to the focus on better build systems and asset management, to the influx of interest from "traditional" mobile developers, there's a lot to take in. Understanding how we reached the present will help us see where we're going next. What problems remain to be solved? How will React Native continue to evolve and grow?

speakers.name: Bonnie Eisenman
speakers.bio: Software eng at Codecademy, NYC Resistor member, author of Learning React Native. Learning Esperanto & Japanese.

Proposals.title: Coffee Break
Proposals.description: Socialize, have some coffee or other drinks.

Proposals.title: The Evolution of React UI Development
Proposals.description:
Hot reloading makes for a great Developer Experience, but we can do even better. Using interactive style guides that show our components in a variety of different states we can test their look and feel in diverse situations.

Collaborate with designers and marketers on testing them and pushing them to their limits. UI fuzz testing can help us discover combinations of props we haven't even thought of so we catch potential UI issues early on.

In the future, we might be able to detect styling and layout issues. Integrating these checks into our Continuous Integration system means we could catch potential problems with our components before any user can see them.

speakers.name: Max Stoiber
speakers.past_experience: I have given a few talks at local meetups in front of 50-100 devs before. Two of them were recorded, see http://mxs.is/pctalk and http://mxs.is/swtalk
speakers.bio: I travel around the world, brew rad coffee, ski beautiful mountains and make stuff on the web. Co-organiser of React Vienna.

speakers.name: Nik Graf
speakers.past_experience: I gave an introductory talk on React and Redux which was featured in the React Newsletter. (http://bit.ly/1nuDWxY) We have yet to present this talk, but we'll do a test run at Stripe and React Vienna. (which I co-founded)
speakers.bio: I care a lot about consistent and easy to grasp user interfaces. While working as a freelancer I created the React UI library Belle and co-founded the React Vienna Meetup. I was invited to Stripe's Open Source Retreat and currently work full-time on several React & Redux open source projects.

Proposals.title: Recomposing your React application
Proposals.description: Recompose is a functional utility library for React components. It provides a suite of higher-order components that encapsulate common React patterns. In this talk, I‚Äôll describe the history and rationale of the library, and discuss strategies for building React apps for scalability and reuse.

speakers.name: Andrew Clark
speakers.bio: Engineer at OpenGov. Currently living in React / JavaScript / Node -land. He's a prolific contributor to projects such as flummox, recompose, redux & more.

Proposals.title: French Buffet
Proposals.description: Lunch time! Socialize while eating at our delicious buffet.

Proposals.title: JavaScript, React Native and Performance.
Proposals.description: With React Native, some of your applications core functionalities, that would previously be written in native code, are now implemented in JavaScript. And that's great! Now you can use things like Hot Module Reloading and ship updates to your app whenever you want. But what about performance and User Experience? Is JavaScript fast enough to replace native code? I'm going to talk about some of the challenges we are working on at the React Native Performance team.

speakers.name: Tadeu Zagallo
speakers.bio: Software Engineer @Facebook working on React Native and one of its top committer.

Proposals.title: Falcor: One Model Everywhere
Proposals.description:
Imagine how easy building your web application would be if all of your data was available in-memory on the client. Falcor lets you to code that way.

Falcor is the open-source, JS data access framework that powers Netflix. Falcor lets you represent all of your cloud data sources as one virtual JSON model on the server. On the client, Falcor makes it appear as if the entire JSON model is available locally and allows you to access data the same way you would from an in-memory JSON object. Falcor retrieves the model data you request from the cloud on-demand, transparently handling all the network communication and keeping the server and client in sync.

Come learn about how Netflix integrates React and Falcor.

speakers.name: Jafar Husain
speakers.bio: Technical Lead at Netflix, Architect of @falcorjs, TC-39 Representative.

Proposals.title: Coffee Break
Proposals.description: Socialize, have some coffee or other drinks.

Proposals.title: React with feeds and other long lists
Proposals.description:
It turns out that one of the most important APIs to be familiar with for mobile development is your platform's list API -- whether that's UITableView on iOS or ListView on Android. React Native has components called ListView and WindowedListView, which are currently our best options in the core for "efficient display of vertically scrolling lists of changing data." If I've lost you because you come from a web background, think FixedDataTable or react-virtualized.

Great, problem solved? For some use cases, yes, but our components don't quite work as well as the native counterparts (some would consider this to be a heinous understatement). I'll give you some background here on what ListViews are, where I've personally run into problems, why they are hard, and what optimizations are currently being done. I hope that afterwards you'll feel more confident building your own list views and contributing to discussions.

speakers.name: Brent Vatne
speakers.bio: Front-end web/mobile developer working on Exponent (exponentjs.com) and one of React Native top committers.

Proposals.title: GraphQL Future
Proposals.description: nc

speakers.name: Lee Byron
speakers.bio: Making things at Facebook since 2008: React, GraphQL, Immutable.js, Mobile, JavaScript.

speakers.name: Laney Kuenzel
speakers.bio: Software engineer at Facebook Boston working on subscriptions in GraphQL.

Proposals.title: Coffee Break
Proposals.description: Socialize, have some coffee or other drinks.

Proposals.title: Progressive enhancement for mobile apps: exploring the continuum between web apps and React Native
Proposals.description:
Rather than looking at web apps and React Native as two separate technologies that mobile developers have to choose between, these approaches can be seen as part of a continuum that allows for progressive enhancement. It should be possible to build apps from a shared codebase that work out of the box on both desktop and mobile devices, but that can be iterated on to get you all the way to a fully native user experience for the parts where this makes sense.

The React programming model is especially suited for this, both because of its focus on composability, and because it has shown that a JavaScript UI framework does not have to be dependent on the DOM. This talk will explore how this model makes it possible to reuse components between web and native platforms, and may even allow for ways to seamlessly mix native views and web elements within a single component tree. It will also discuss ongoing work on establishing a common API surface for accessing device-native features.

speakers.name: Martijn Walraven
speakers.bio: Martijn Walraven is a core developer at Meteor Development Group, where he works on mobile support for the Meteor JavaScript app platform, including the Cordova integration. He is also the creator of Meteor iOS, which integrates native iOS apps with Meteor.

Proposals.title: Q&A Panel
Proposals.description: This is your opportunity to ask questions to the team. Use the tag #AskReactEu on twitter and we'll forward them your question.

Proposals.title: Drink up
Proposals.description: Have a last drink before leaving.

DiamondSponsors.Name: Rangle.io
DiamondSponsors.Description: Rangle.io is North America's leading next-generation full-stack JavaScript design and development firm. Dedicated to well-crafted responsive web and mobile applications, we only work with modern JavaScript, HTML5, and CSS. Our specialities include Angular, React, Node, Ionic, Meteor, Backbone and other modern JavaScript technologies. As strong functional programming advocates, we lean towards functional reactive programming (FRP) for more complex applications. We are a pioneer in Lean UX and our integrated Agile design and development methodologies allow us to start delivering value quickly and continuously, enabling our clients to quickly test and validate their features and business model on an ongoing basis. With over two dozen modern JavaScript projects delivered in the last two years, we are the partner of choice for companies starting a new project or migrating to modern HTML5 web and mobile applications.

GoldSponsors.Name: Red Badger
GoldSponsors.Description: Red Badger is a creative software workshop in East London. We love to craft. We love to innovate. And more than anything, we love to create beautiful, compelling experiences built around robust technologies. We work for clients such as Fortnum & Mason, BSkyB, Tesco and the BBC. We love React.js and run the brilliant React meetup in London.

GoldSponsors.Name: Automattic
GoldSponsors.Description: Automattic is a distributed company, democratizing publishing and development. We are the people behind WordPress.com, which serves more than 15.8 billion pages a month, as well as a host of other popular services, such as Akismet, Jetpack, and VaultPress. We are strong believers in Open Source, and the vast majority of our work is available under licenses like the GPL. Our team members hail from nearly every continent and 36 countries around the world. We are hiring! Learn more at http://automattic.com.

GoldSponsors.Name: Shoutem
GoldSponsors.Description: Shoutem's mission is to supercharge React Native development. 80% of the app development is boilerplate. Let us handle, while you focus on developing the unique parts of your app. Use over 20+ open sourced extensions written 100% in React Native. Modify them or write your own from scratch.

GoldSponsors.Name: Coursio
GoldSponsors.Description: We are refactoring education to be bidirectional using the best unidirectional data flow library out there.

GoldSponsors.Name: Zalando SE
GoldSponsors.Description: Zalando is transforming from an e-commerce company into a multi-service platform that provides fashion as a service. We make it our mission to imagine and predict the infinite points of interaction between fashion and people - and develop the technology to make them possible. Our 1000+ technologists build most of our products in-house and open source, from our logistics software to our mobile applications.

GoldSponsors.Name: Heroku
GoldSponsors.Description: Heroku, a Salesforce company and industry pioneer in platform as a service (PaaS), enables developers to build and run applications entirely in the cloud, without the need to purchase or maintain any servers or software. With Heroku you can focus on your app, not your infrastructure.

GoldSponsors.Name: Monaca Onsen UI
GoldSponsors.Description: Onsen UI bundles a rich collection of React Components and supports flat (iOS) and Material Design (Android) equally, giving a native look and feel to hybrid apps. It is part of the Monaca Cloud Platform.

SilverSponsors.Name: Ekino
SilverSponsors.Description:
Understand and analyse business expectations.

Build and enhance customer experiences through innovation. Integrate cutting-edge technologies into our client‚Äôs information systems: this is the new model of agency we established in order to address digital transformation issues.

Ekino develops and industrializes your digital services.  We are a team of 200 digital enthusiasts, part of the Havas Group, supporting businesses in their digital initiatives from ideation to realization. It is because we all share the same culture that we successfully design, develop and industrialize all kinds of digital services. From international groups, such as SFR, Renault or the Canal Group, to startups, we have always met our challenges with the same passion for what we do: enable our clients to make the best use of digital technology.

BronzeSponsors.Name: bitcrowd
BronzeSponsors.Description: Bitcrowd provides quality software development for startups in every livecycle. Clients hire us because we bring our experience, skill and passion to their project. We give advice, conceptualise, design and implement your application using state-of-the-art technologies likeRails and ReactJS.

BronzeSponsors.Name: JoliCode

PartnersSponsors.Name: EventLama
PartnersSponsors.Description:
EventLama is built and used by people who run big tech events. We know it's a lot of work, you need to build a web site, a mobile app, add speakers one by one, set up a call for paper, manage sponsors keep track of social media, manage orders, tickets, refunds, leads and more! 
We make all these daunting tasks just one click away so you can relax and spend more time focusing on making your attendee experience awesome with great innovative features that will make your customers love you.

PartnersSponsors.Name: exponent.js
PartnersSponsors.Description:
Exponent brings together the best of web (development speed, fast iteration cycles, easy deploys, automatic cross-platform support, and simple sharing with URLs) and the performance and user experience of native apps.

With Exponent, you can write iOS and Android experiences in JavaScript using React Native, without Xcode or Android Studio, and share them with anyone else who has the app in a single click.

PartnersSponsors.Name: socialtables
PartnersSponsors.Description: The #1 software for planners and properties to work together online

PartnersSponsors.Name: x-team
PartnersSponsors.Description: X-Team is trusted by the world's leading brands, providing high-quality developers when you need them most since 2006.
